name: sodium silicate production, spray powder, 80% | sodium silicate, spray powder, 80% | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/783/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of sodium silicate powder (80%) from sodium silicate (48% in water) by the hydrothermal process. There are currently three principal areas of use for sodium silicates: as a raw material in detergents, as a starting material for the chemical industry, and as an adhesive in various fields. In detergents, sodium silicates serve as builder, corrosion inhibitor and additive. Material and energy inputs as well as waste production and emission to air and water are based on literature sources. The infrastructure is estimated based on a large chemical plant.;References:;Zah R., Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Detergents. ecoinvent report No. 12. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.

From reception of sodium silicate (hydrothermal liquor, 48 % in water) at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of 1 kg of sodium silicate powder (80%). The dataset includes material and energy input, production of waste, emissions and infrastructure.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Average data from 6 European producers. The inventory is assumed to be representative of the global production.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The hydrothermal process is one of the two main processes used to produce sodium silicate, the other one being the furnace process.;In the hydrothermal process, sand is dissolved in sodium hydroxide. This process is carried out under high temperature and pressure in an autoclave. After filtration sodium silicate is obtained in a 48% solution. Spray-drying of the hydrothermal 48% sodium silicate solution obtained after filtration produces a powder of 80%. The sodium silicate solution can be reacted again with sodium hydroxide. Metasilicate crystallises out and can be used in its solid form.;This represents an average technology in Europe.;References:;Zah R., Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Detergents. ecoinvent report No. 12. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data based on questionnaires and literature.

exchanges.description: The solid portions of the surface of the Earth consist predominantly of silicon and oxygen atoms in the form of silica and silicates. The use of Earth’s silica and silicate resources is thus the oldest technology on the planet. Nowadays, the range of application of silica and silicates is mainly in the following three fields: detergents, chemicals, adhesives. As a detergent ingredient or wash alkali, sodium silicates raise the pH value and dirt and textile fibres become more strongly negatively charged increasing their mutual electrostatic repulsion. Apart from this, the hardness components of the water are eliminated by complex formation.

flow.name: sodium silicate, spray powder, 80%
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description: Calculated value: calculation based on literature value. The data reported in the literature refer to a 48% solution of sodium silicate. All chemicals in the dataset use a functional unit referring to 100% of sodium silicate, thus the literature values has been multiplied with a factor of 2.08.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
